head.title: Canadian Hydropower Poses No Dire Threat; New Yorkers Save

hedline.hl1: Canadian Hydropower Poses No Dire Threat; New Yorkers Save

block.p: Events in the Middle East provide more evidence that, if we took John Stanton's advice (letter, July 14) and ended purchases of hydroelectric energy from Quebec, New York City's electricity supply would be less reliable. And the city would be a poorer, more polluted place.

New Yorkers have saved more than $600 million on their electricity bills in the last 12 years thanks to New York Power Authority purchases from Hydro-Quebec. Consumers in the metropolitan area would lose $3 billion in future savings if our new 21-year contract with Hydro-Quebec were not implemented. These savings reflect the fact that the Quebec hydropower costs up to 15 percent less than alternate electricity sources.

Millions of New Yorkers and Canadians would breathe more polluted air if it were necessary to use electricity produced by burning oil or coal instead of the Quebec hydropower. These fuels have been widely blamed for acid rain, the greenhouse effect and other environmental problems that transcend national borders.

Hydroelectric development in the James Bay region of northern Quebec, the focus of Mr. Stanton's concern, would likely proceed even if New York weren't a customer. The new James Bay projects are planned primarily to meet electricity needs in Quebec. Exports to New York and New England will advance their completion dates, but the province would need the projects in any case.

Conservation alone isn't an energy panacea. That's why Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's state energy plan calls for Canadian imports, as well as other measures to insure a reliable, reasonably priced power supply while protecting the environment. The plan recommends New York consider the purchase of 400,000 kilowatts more from Quebec beyond the 1 million kilowatts provided in the new contract.
